questions.text: A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after the sudden onset of severe pain in the middle of his chest. He describes the pain as tearing in quality; it radiates to his jaw. He has hypertension. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 25 years. Current medications include enalapril. His blood pressure is 154/95 mm Hg in his right arm and 181/105 mm Hg in his left arm. A CT scan of the chest is shown. The structure that is damaged in this patient is a derivative of which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The truncus arteriosus forms early in cardiac development at the cranial end of the bulbus cordis and gives rise to the pulmonary trunk and ascending aorta. During cardiac development, neural crest and endocardial cells migrate to form truncal ridges and bulbar ridges from the truncus arteriosus and bulbus cordis, respectively. Truncal and bulbar ridges spiral and fuse to form the aorticopulmonary septum (AP septum), thereby creating the independent ascending aorta and pulmonary trunk. Incomplete formation of the aorticopulmonary septum results in persistent truncus arteriosus, which manifests at birth with cyanosis, heart failure, and a harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border.
Image Description:

During the 4th and 5th weeks of gestation, the straight heart tube (seen on the left) transforms into an S-shaped heart loop. The bulbus cordis and arterial outflow tract bend ventrally, caudally, and to the right, while the primitive atrium bends dorsally, cranially, and to the left until it partially surrounds the outflow tract. The right side of the venous return tract becomes dominant, with the right horn of the sinus venosus forming part of the right atrium and the veins feeding into it forming the superior and inferior venae cavae.

B) INCORRECT:

The right common cardinal vein, together with the right anterior cardinal vein, form the superior vena cava, not the ascending aorta.

C) INCORRECT:

The bulbus cordis, connected to the primitive ventricle on its caudal end and the truncus arteriosus on its cranial end, is a region of the embryonic heart that gives rise to the outflow tract of the right and left ventricle, not the ascending aorta.

D) INCORRECT:

The primitive atrium partially surrounds the bulbus cordis and gives rise to the trabeculated portion of the right and left atrium, not the ascending aorta.

E) INCORRECT:

The right horn of the sinus venosus gives rise to the smooth part of the right atrium, not the ascending aorta. Meanwhile, the smooth part of the left atrium derives from the primitive pulmonary vein.
questions.hint: This patient's sudden-onset tearing chest pain and asymmetrical blood pressure readings in conjunction with the CT scan findings suggest dissection of the ascending aorta.

questions.text: Shortly after delivery, a female newborn develops bluish discoloration of the lips, fingers, and toes. She was born at term to a 38-year-old primigravid woman. Pregnancy was complicated by maternal diabetes mellitus. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 81%. Echocardiography shows immediate bifurcation of the vessel arising from the left ventricle; the vessel emerging from the right ventricle gives out coronary, head, and neck vessels. An abnormality in which of the following developmental processes most likely accounts for this patient's condition?

choices.text: Separation of tricuspid valve tissue from myocardium
Division of aorta and pulmonary artery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Failed separation of tricuspid valve tissue from myocardium causes Ebstein anomaly. Mild apical displacement is often asymptomatic, whereas individuals with marked tricuspid valve leaflet displacement and incompetence can present with cyanosis due to right-to-left shunting (interatrial) and poor oxygen saturation, as observed in this patient. However, echocardiography would show apical displacement of the septal tricuspid valve leaflet, not transposition of the great vessels.
Image Description:

In the Ebstein anomaly, the tricuspid valve is displaced into the lumen of the right ventricle, resulting in atrialization of the right ventricle. The remaining ventricle is small and hypocontractile. Because tricuspid valve regurgitation is also usually present, there is retrograde flow in the right atrium, which is dilated by the volume overload, in addition to antegrade pulmonary blood flow. Blood flows through the patent foramen ovale or (commonly associated) atrial septal defect from the right atrium to the left atrium (right-to-left shunt) and then via the left ventricle into the circulation, resulting in pronounced cyanosis. The pulmonary circulation system may also be perfused through blood from the aorta (via the ductus arteriosus).

B) INCORRECT:

Impaired fusion of the endocardial cushion can cause atrial septal defect, ventricular septal defect, or atrioventricular septal defects, all of which are usually asymptomatic at birth. Infants with complete atrioventricular septal defects can present with symptoms of heart failure. Untreated, these defects can cause significant pulmonary hypertension and reversal of the left-to-right shunt (Eisenmenger syndrome). However, early cyanosis is not typical and echocardiography will show the respective septal defect, not transposition of the great vessels.
Image Description:

A defect in the ventricular septum leads to a left-to-right shunt, the volume of which is dependent on the size of the defect. Blood flows from the left ventricle to the right ventricle (white arrow) along the pressure gradient (1). This leads to increased RV and LV preload (due to increased end-diastolic volume), ventricular hypertrophy and dilation (double-headed white arrows), and pulmonary hypertension resulting from excessive pulmonary blood flow (2). In end-stage disease, the pressure gradient is reversed because of Eisenmenger syndrome (shunt reversal), leading to the flow of mixed blood to the systemic circulation (white arrow) and subsequent cyanosis (3).

Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

C) INCORRECT:

Anterosuperior displacement of the infundibular septum is one of the features in tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) that causes infundibular pulmonary stenosis, TOF's key prognostic determinant. Infants with TOF can present with early cyanosis and poor oxygen saturation, as observed in this newborn. However, echocardiography would show the presence of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction and hypertrophy, overriding aorta, and ventricular septal defect, not transposition of the great vessels.
Image Description:

Tetralogy of Fallot is the simultaneous occurrence of:
(a) Pulmonary stenosis
(b) Right ventricular hypertrophy
(c) Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
(d) An overriding aorta (above the VSD)

The hemodynamic effects depend on the extent of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. With mild obstruction (1), a left-to-right shunt is more pronounced and there is mild cyanosis. With severe obstruction (2), a right-to-left shunt is more pronounced, which results in severe cyanosis. Pulmonary circulation may be supplied via a patent ductus arteriosus.

D) INCORRECT:

Failed development of a septum dividing the aorta and pulmonary artery causes persistent truncus arteriosus. In patients with truncus arteriosus, a common trunk arises from both the right and left ventricle, mixing arterial and venous blood. Infants will present with early cyanosis and poor oxygen saturation, as observed in this patient. However, echocardiography will show a single overriding vessel connected to both ventricles, not transposition of the great vessels.

E) CORRECT:

In the development of the cardiac outflow tract, neural crest and endocardial cells migrate to form truncal ridges and bulbar ridges from the truncus arteriosus and bulbus cordis, respectively. Normally, the truncal and bulbar ridges spiral and fuse to form the aorticopulmonary septum (AP septum), which further develops into the ascending aorta and pulmonary trunk. Transposition of the great vessels (TGV) occurs when the aorticopulmonary septum fails to spiral. Infants born to mothers with diabetes are at increased risk of developing TGV.

TGV is incompatible with life unless mixing occurs via an intracardiac shunt across a patent foramen ovale, ventricle septal defect, or atrial septal defect, or via an extracardiac connection (e.g., patent ductus arteriosus).
Image Description:

I: Development of the muscular interventricular septum and interventricular foramen
- The primary ventricle is a single cavity that is separated from the atrial cavity by the endocardial cushion. Ventricular septation begins with the formation of a muscular interventricular septum, which arises from the floor of the primitive ventricle and grows cranially toward the endocardial cushion. The interventricular foramen is the space between the endocardial cushion and the growing edge of the muscular interventricular septum and it allows for interventricular communication.

II: Development of the aorticopulmonary septum
- The aorticopulmonary septum develops from ridges of tissue derived from neural crest cells within the ventricular outflow tract (truncus arteriosus). These ridges are continuous with the bulbar ridges of the bulbar cordis (not shown here).

III: Development of the membranous interventricular septum and closure of the interventricular foramen
- The membranous interventricular septum develops from the bulbar ridges and the endocardial cushion.
- The caudal end of the aorticopulmonary septum fuses with the muscular interventricular septum and closes the interventricular foramen.

IV: Division of the ventricular outflow tract
- The aorticopulmonary septum fuses and rotates 180Â°, dividing the outflow tract into the aorta (from the left ventricle) and pulmonary trunk (from the right ventricle).
questions.hint: Echocardiography shows the pulmonary trunk arising (posteriorly) from the left ventricle, and the aorta (which gives out coronary, head, and neck arteries) arising (anteriorly) from the right ventricle, which is called transposition of the great vessels. Early cyanosis and poor oxygen saturation are consistent with this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of progressive fatigue, shortness of breath, and palpitations. She has a history of recurrent episodes of joint pain and fever during childhood. She emigrated from India with her parents when she was 10 years old. Cardiac examination shows an opening snap followed by a late diastolic rumble, which is best heard at the fifth intercostal space in the left midclavicular line. This patient is at greatest risk for compression of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The trachea terminates by bifurcating into the right and left bronchi superior to the left atrium. Therefore, cardiac compression of the trachea is unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

The thoracic duct lies in the posterior mediastinum and is separated from the heart by the descending thoracic aorta and the esophagus. It is therefore unlikely to be compressed by cardiac enlargement.

C) INCORRECT:

The vagus nerves lie posterior to the hila of the lungs bilaterally. They are therefore unlikely to be compressed by cardiac enlargement. In rare cases, compression of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve by a significantly enlarged left atrium may occur in patients with chronic mitral stenosis. Patients may then present with hoarseness of voice.

D) INCORRECT:

The hemiazygos vein lies in the posterior mediastinum, which is separated from the heart by the descending thoracic aorta and the esophagus. It is therefore unlikely to be compressed by cardiac enlargement.

E) CORRECT:

Because the posterior mediastinal portion of the esophagus lies just behind the left atrium, it is at risk of being compressed and/or displaced by an enlarged left atrium. Left atrial enlargement due to increased left atrial pressure can develop in patients with chronic mitral stenosis, although this occurs very rarely.
questions.hint: This patient's murmur is characteristic of mitral stenosis, which, given her immigration history and recurrent fever and joint pain, is most likely secondary to rheumatic fever. Untreated chronic mitral stenosis results in left atrium dilation, which can compress adjacent structures.

questions.text: A 3175-g (7-lb) male newborn is delivered at 39 weeks' gestation to a 29-year-old primigravid woman following a spontaneous vaginal delivery. Apgar scores are 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Cardiac examination in the delivery room shows a continuous machine-like murmur. An echocardiogram shows a structure with blood flow between the pulmonary artery and the aorta. This structure is most likely a derivate of which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The 4th aortic arch develops into the aortic arch on the left and the proximal part of the right subclavian artery on the right. The ductus arteriosus does not develop from the 4th aortic arch.

B) INCORRECT:

The 2nd aortic arch develops into the stapedial artery and the hyoid artery. The ductus arteriosus does not develop from the 2ndaortic arch.

C) CORRECT:

The 6th aortic arch is the origin of the proximal parts of the left and right pulmonary arteries and the ductus arteriosus (on the left side only).
Image Description:

The aortic arches develop in craniocaudal order, with the first two arches obliterating early. Not shown: a remnant of the first aortic arch forms part of the maxillary artery, and a remnant of the second aortic arch forms the hyoid artery. The second arch also forms the stapedial artery, which typically regresses around week 10 of development.

The third aortic arch gives rise to the common carotid and proximal internal carotid.

On the right, the fourth aortic arch gives rise to the proximal right subclavian artery. On the left, the fourth aortic arch gives rise to a portion of the aortic arch from left common carotid to left subclavian.

The fifth aortic arch either never develops or obliterates without giving rise to a vessel.

On the right, the sixth aortic arch gives rise to the right pulmonary artery. On the left, the sixth aortic arch gives rise to the left pulmonary artery and ductus arteriosus.

D) INCORRECT:

The 1st aortic arch is the origin of the maxillary artery. The ductus arteriosus does not develop from the 1st aortic arch.

E) INCORRECT:

The 3rd aortic arch develops into the common carotid artery and proximal part of the internal carotid artery. The ductus arteriosus does not develop from the 3rd aortic arch.
questions.hint: This newborn's examination shows a structure between the pulmonary artery and aorta with a continuous âmachine-likeâ murmur heard on cardiac auscultation. This is characteristic of a patent ductus arteriosus.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 4-month history of fatigue, shortness of breath with exertion, and dizziness. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and had a single-chamber pacemaker placed five years ago after an episode of syncope. Her pulse is 66/min and blood pressure is 98/66 mm Hg. An x-ray of the chest is shown. The x-ray confirms termination of the pacemaker lead in which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pacemaker wires travel through the superior vena cava (SVC) in order to enter the heart. They should, however, terminate in a structure other than the SVC to be effective. On a posteroanterior x-ray of the chest, the SVC is superior to the right lateral aspect of the cardiac contour. The lead in this patient's x-ray terminates inferior and to the left of the SVC.

B) INCORRECT:

Left ventricular pacemaker leads are almost exclusively seen with biventricular pacemakers, which have leads terminating in both the right and the left ventricles. During biventricular pacemaker placement, the left ventricular lead is passed through the coronary sinus into a coronary vein (usually the lateral or posterolateral branch), from which the lead then paces the left ventricle transvenously. On a posteroanterior x-ray of the chest, a left ventricle lead would be visualized as crossing from the right atrium into the coronary sinus and then following a lateral course along the left heart contour. This patient's finding of a single pacer lead and history of atrial fibrillation are not consistent with a left ventricular pacemaker.

Biventricular pacemakers are used to treat abnormal intraventricular conduction, such as a left bundle branch block.

C) CORRECT:

The right ventricle makes up the anterior contour of the heart and is centered on the anterior mediastinal plane on a lateral chest x-ray. In a PA chest x-ray, the right ventricle does not contribute to any of the visible heart contours (the right heart contour is composed primarily of the right atrium), which can make its identification difficult. However, this patient's chest x-ray clearly shows her single-chamber pacing lead course through the right subclavian vein, superior vena cava, and right atrium before terminating in the region of the right ventricle.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (left: PA view; right: lateral view) of an adult female patient

The lung volumes are normal. No abnormal pulmonary parenchymal opacities are seen. The cardiac silhouette size and shape are normal. The costophrenic sulci are sharp, with no evidence of effusion. No concerning skeletal lesions are identified.

On the lateral radiograph (right), the patient's upper arms (black dashed lines) obscure the retrosternal space. Furthermore, the lower thorax is slightly rotated with the left side anterior; note the stomach bubble (S) under the left hemidiaphragm and the projection of the left posterior costophrenic sulcus (dashed yellow line) anterior to the right (dashed blue line).

A: aorta
PT: pulmonary trunk
LA: left atrium
S: stomach
SVC: superior vena cava
IVC: inferior vena cava
Dashed white lines: margins of superior and inferior vena cavae
White line: aortopulmonary reflection (aortic-pulmonary reflection)
Yellow overlay: right atrium
Green overlay: right ventricle
Red overlay: left ventricle
Blue overlay: left atrium
Blue incomplete circle: left main to left upper lobe bronchus continuum
Dashed green line: posterior wall of bronchus intermedius
Green line: posterior wall of left main bronchus
Red line: top of left pulmonary artery
Blue line: aortic arch
Yellow lines: edges of scapulae

D) INCORRECT:

On a posteroanterior x-ray of the chest, the left atrium sits posteriorly and therefore is not readily visible apart from the left atrial appendage, which is visualized at the superior left lateral border of the heart. The lead in this patient's x-ray terminates inferior to and to the right of the left atrial appendage.

E) INCORRECT:

A single chamber pacemaker with a lead placed in the right atrium can be used in the treatment of sick sinus syndrome. On a posteroanterior x-ray of the chest, the right atrium makes up the right heart contour and is located to the lateral right of the mediastinum. The lead in this patient's x-ray, however, terminates to the left of the anterior mediastinum.
questions.hint: This patient's history and presentation are consistent with pacemaker syndrome, in which there is dysynchrony between the atria and ventricles. The image shows a posterioranterior (PA) chest x-ray with a single pacemaker lead.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of decreased appetite and abdominal pain for the last several weeks. Physical examination shows a palpable left-sided abdominal mass that does not cross the midline. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a large, necrotic tumor on the left kidney. Histological examination of the kidney mass shows primitive blastemal cells and immature tubules and glomeruli. This tissue is most likely derived from the same embryological structure as which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The carotid body contains cells derived from the neural crest. Neural crest cells form specialized structures, such as the sympathetic ganglia, the adrenal medulla, and melanocytes. This patient's tumor is derived from renal progenitor cells, not neural crest cells.

B) INCORRECT:

The adrenal medulla is derived from neural crest cells. Neural crest cells originate from the neuroectoderm and give rise to structures of the PNS (e.g., ganglia, cranial nerves, Schwann cells), and other cells such as melanocytes and odontoblasts. Renal progenitor cells that form the tumor in this patient are not derived from neural crest cells.

The adrenal cortex is derived from mesoderm.

C) INCORRECT:

The thyroid gland parenchyma consists of follicular cells and parafollicular cells (C cells), which are derived from endodermal cells of the floor of the pharynx. The endoderm also gives rise to the pharyngeal pouches, the epithelium of the stomach and intestine, and the pancreas, liver, and gallbladder. Renal progenitor cells that form the tumor in this patient are not derived from the endoderm.

D) CORRECT:

The papillary muscles of the heart are derived from the mesoderm. The mesoderm is the embryonic progenitor of all muscles (cardiac muscle, smooth muscle, and skeletal muscle), the kidneys, ureters, vessels, bone, cartilage, and many cells of the reproductive system. This patient's nephroblastoma is a tumor of renal progenitor cells.

Formation of the aorticopulmonary septum from the truncus arteriosus and bulbus cordis, and thus the development of the aorta and pulmonary trunks, involves caudal migration of the neural crest cells.
Image Description:

Adult derivatives of mesoderm (not all derivatives are shown)

Paraxial mesoderm derivatives include the vertebrae, annulus fibrosus of the intervertebral discs, and ribs.

Lateral plate mesoderm derivatives include the heart.

Intermediate mesoderm derivatives include the kidneys.

Somatic (somatopleuric) mesoderm derivatives include parietal (outer) pericardial, pleural, and peritoneal linings.

Splanchnic mesoderm derivatives include connective tissue and smooth muscle of the intestinal wall, and visceral (inner) pericardial, pleural, and peritoneal linings.

E) INCORRECT:

The anterior pituitary gland originates from the surface ectoderm. The surface ectoderm is a germ layer derived from the ectoderm. It gives rise to the epidermis, hair, nails, inner ear, external ear, tooth enamel, eye lens, anterior pituitary, parotid gland, and anal canal (below the pectinate line). This patient's tumor histology indicates the embryological source as primitive renal cells, which are not derived from the ectoderm.
questions.hint: Nephroblastoma (Wilms tumor) is a tumor comprised of renal progenitor cells, including rhabdomyoblasts. Embryologically, the kidneys derive from the mesoderm.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the physiological factors involved in regulating coronary vessel blood flow during high metabolic activity in healthy human volunteers. In addition to the direct effects of coronary venous oxygen and carbon dioxide concentrations, the effects of adenosine, ATP-dependent potassium channels, and adrenergic activity on coronary vasodilation are examined. The volunteers undergo cardiac catheterization to measure left ventricular, left atrial, and aortic pressures. An image of the pressure tracings in one healthy volunteer is shown. Blood flow through the coronary arteries is most likely to peak at which of the following labeled points of the diagram?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This point marks the onset of the isovolumetric contraction phase of systole and closure of the mitral valve. The blood flow through the coronary vessels would peak at a different point in the cardiac cycle.

B) INCORRECT:

This point marks the onset of the rapid ejection phase of systole and the opening of the aortic valve, identified by the sudden rise in aortic pressure. The blood flow through the coronary vessels would peak at a different point in the cardiac cycle.

C) INCORRECT:

This point marks peak systolic pressure in both the ventricle and the aorta. The blood flow through peripheral arteries would reach its peak at this point in the cardiac cycle, but the blood flow through the coronary vessels would reach its nadir.

D) INCORRECT:

This point marks the onset of the isovolumetric relaxation phase of ventricular diastole and the closure of the aortic valve. The blood flow through the coronary vessels would peak at a different point in the cardiac cycle.

E) CORRECT:

In most peripheral arteries, blood flow peaks at the end of the rapid ejection phase of systole when the ventricular and aortic pressures are the highest (point C). However, coronary arteries, which arise from the aortic root, are unique because they are embedded within the ventricular myocardium and are compressed when ventricular wall tension increases. Therefore, blood flow through the coronary vessels occurs predominantly during diastole when the ventricular pressure is lower than the aortic pressure. Thus, the point of peak coronary flow in the cardiac cycle occurs when the pressure differential between the aorta and the left ventricle is the greatest (point E during early diastole).

During exercise, the shortened duration of diastole is a limiting factor for coronary blood flow.
Image Description:

1: The mitral valve closes and ventricular contraction begins (ventricular systole).
1â2: There is an isovolumetric contraction of the left ventricle until its pressure is higher than that of the aorta.
2: The pressure within the left ventricle (blue line) exceeds that of the aorta, causing the aortic valve to open.
2â3: The ventricle continues to contract and ejects blood into the aorta, increasing the ventricular and aortic pressures.
3: The aortic valve closes when the ventricular pressure falls below the aortic pressure, marking the beginning of diastole.
3â4: Ventricular pressure falls rapidly with ventricular relaxation. There is a small upstroke in aortic pressure (yellow line) after the aortic valve closes (dicrotic notch), followed by a more gradual decrease in pressure because of its inherent vascular resistance.
4: The mitral valve opens when the ventricular pressure falls below the atrial pressure and ventricular filling begins.

The atrial pressure curve (green line) shows three upstrokes.
â a wave: just before 1, when the left atrium contracts
â c wave: just after 1, due to transmitted pressure from the contracting ventricle
â v wave: at 4, when the atrium receives blood from the vena cava

F) INCORRECT:

This point marks the slow filling phase of ventricular diastole and the onset of atrial contraction (âatrial kickâ). The blood flow through the coronary vessels would peak at a different point in the cardiac cycle.
questions.hint: External compression of the coronary vessels by myocardial tissue results in paradoxical peak flow.

questions.text: A 5-day-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 2-day history of difficulty feeding and multiple episodes of his lips turning blue. He was born at home via spontaneous vaginal delivery and Apgar scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Physical examination shows grunting and moderate intercostal and subcostal retractions. Echocardiography shows a single vessel exiting from the heart. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Failure of neural crest cell migration
Abnormal placement of the infundibular septum
Absent fusion of septum primum and septum secundum

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

During cardiac development, failure of neural crest cell migration leads to a lack of aorticopulmonary septum formation, resulting in a single outflow vessel that receives output from both the right and left ventricles; this condition is known as persistent truncus arteriosus. The mixing of oxygen-rich blood from the left ventricle with the oxygen-poor blood from the right ventricle leads to a decrease in overall oxygenation of the blood going into the systemic circulation, causing cyanosis, as seen in this patient with episodic blue lips. This patient also has poor feeding, grunting, and intercostal and subcostal retractions, which are concerning for respiratory distress caused by pulmonary congestion secondary to an increase in overall blood flow to the lungs.
Image Description:

Persistent truncus arteriosus (PTA) is a congenital cyanotic heart defect in which the truncus arteriosus fails to divide into the pulmonary trunk and aorta and instead remains as a single trunk that receives blood from both ventricles. The pulmonary circulation and systemic circulation are not separated from one another, therefore, deoxygenated and oxygenated blood mix.

After birth, the pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) drops, resulting in blood being shunted to the pulmonary circulation, leading to pulmonary congestion and subsequent heart failure.

B) INCORRECT:

Insufficient growth of endocardial cushions leads to defects in the atrial and ventricular septa, resulting in atrial septal defects (ASD) and ventricular septal defects (VSD), respectively. Large defects in the cardiac septa can lead to pulmonary hypertension as a result of left-to-right shunting, which would explain this patient's respiratory distress. While there is a strong association between a persistent truncus arteriosus and a large VSD, patients with only an ASD or VSD are usually acyanotic, and the echocardiography should only show the septal defect with a normal cardiac outflow tract.
Image Description:

A defect in the ventricular septum leads to a left-to-right shunt, the volume of which is dependent on the size of the defect. Blood flows from the left ventricle to the right ventricle (white arrow) along the pressure gradient (1). This leads to increased RV and LV preload (due to increased end-diastolic volume), ventricular hypertrophy and dilation (double-headed white arrows), and pulmonary hypertension resulting from excessive pulmonary blood flow (2). In end-stage disease, the pressure gradient is reversed because of Eisenmenger syndrome (shunt reversal), leading to the flow of mixed blood to the systemic circulation (white arrow) and subsequent cyanosis (3).

Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

C) INCORRECT:

Abnormal placement of the infundibular septum leads to the characteristic findings in Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). While TOF can also lead to the blue lips and respiratory distress seen in this patient, an echocardiography would instead show right ventricular outflow tract obstruction, right ventricular hypertrophy, VSD, and an overriding aorta.
Image Description:

Tetralogy of Fallot is the simultaneous occurrence of:
(a) Pulmonary stenosis
(b) Right ventricular hypertrophy
(c) Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
(d) An overriding aorta (above the VSD)

The hemodynamic effects depend on the extent of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. With mild obstruction (1), a left-to-right shunt is more pronounced and there is mild cyanosis. With severe obstruction (2), a right-to-left shunt is more pronounced, which results in severe cyanosis. Pulmonary circulation may be supplied via a patent ductus arteriosus.

D) INCORRECT:

Absent fusion of the septum primum and septum secundum leads to an opening in the atrial septum known as a patent foramen ovale (PFO). A PFO causes a mild left-to-right shunt that is usually asymptomatic and does not cause cyanosis or respiratory distress, unlike in this patient. Also, an echocardiography would instead show a shunt caused by the patent opening and a normal cardiac outflow tract.

E) INCORRECT:

Abnormal cardiac looping results in an abnormal arrangement of the heart (e.g., dextrocardia), typically in a condition known as Kartagener syndrome. Kartagener syndrome may cause respiratory distress (as in this patient) due to dysfunctional cilia of the respiratory epithelium, as well as recurrent sinusitis and otitis, hearing loss, and impaired fertility. However, echocardiography would instead show a heart in the right side of the thorax.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms (poor feeding, cyanosis, respiratory distress) in early infancy and echocardiography results are consistent with persistent truncus arteriosus.
